company.name: ChoicePoint Inc.
company.business_description: ChoicePoint collects and maintains personal identifying information about individuals and furnishes that information to subscribers for a fee. The company sells consumer reports obtained from consumer reporting agencies and public record information from various sources, providing products and services to businesses, governments, and other entities for identification and credential verification purposes.

case_info.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 621(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681s(a)

complaint.factual_background: ChoicePoint Inc., a Georgia corporation, collected and maintained vast databases of personal consumer information—including Social Security numbers, dates of birth, credit histories, and financial account data—and sold this information to subscribers who were supposed to have lawful purposes. ChoicePoint failed to implement reasonable procedures to verify the identities and qualifications of prospective subscribers, allowing fraudulent actors to gain access to the personal information of approximately 163,000 consumers, resulting in at least 800 confirmed identity theft cases. ChoicePoint also failed to monitor existing subscriber activity for red flags of unauthorized use, even after receiving law enforcement subpoenas alerting it to fraudulent accounts. Despite these failures, ChoicePoint publicly represented through its websites, subscriber contracts, and SEC filings that it used rigorous credentialing processes, maintained strong safeguards to protect consumer data, and monitored subscriber use to ensure appropriate access. These representations were false and misleading, and ChoicePoint's conduct violated both the Fair Credit Reporting Act and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act.

representations_made.description: Claimed to use administrative, technical, personnel, and physical safeguards to protect the confidentiality and security of personally identifiable consumer information, with safeguards designed to ensure a level of security appropriate to the nature of the data and the risks involved
representations_made.quoted_text: ChoicePoint uses administrative, technical, personnel, and physical safeguards to protect the confidentiality and security of personally identifiable consumer information in our possession. These safeguards are designed to ensure a level of security appropriate to the nature of the data being processed and the risks of confidentiality violations involved.

representations_made.description: Claimed to treat consumers fairly, protect their privacy through Fair Information Practices that go beyond the requirements of the FCRA, and to allow access to consumer reports only by those authorized under the FCRA, with each customer required to verify a permissible purpose before receiving a consumer report
representations_made.quoted_text: Because ChoicePomt's ChoiceTrust understands its responsibility to treat consumers fairly and to protect their privacy, we have developed Fair Information Practices These practices are derived from the Federal Fair Credit Reporting Act, but go beyond the requirements of that law . . . ChoicePoint operated under its own Fair Information Practices even before passage of this Act, and continues to offer greater protection to the consumer than is required by the FCRA. **~** ChoicePoint allows access to your consumer reports only by those authorized under the FCRA In addition, each ChoicePoint customer must verify that he/she has a `permissible purpose' before receiving a consumer report

representations_made.description: Claimed that every ChoicePoint customer must successfully complete a rigorous credentialing process, that ChoicePoint does not distribute information to the general public, and that it monitors the use of its public record information to ensure appropriate use
representations_made.quoted_text: Every ChoicePoint customer must successfully complete a rigorous credentialmg process. ChoicePoint does not distribute information 10 Case 1:06-cv-00198-GET Document 1-1 Filed 01/30/2006 Page 11 of 33(cid:10) to the general public and monitors the use of its public record information to ensure appropriate use.

counts.title: Furnishing Consumer Reports Without Permissible Purpose (FCRA § 604)
counts.representation: ChoicePoint furnished consumer reports to subscribers who had submitted applications containing false credentials and misrepresentations, which ChoicePoint approved without adequate verification.
counts.fact: Section 604 of the FCRA prohibits a consumer reporting agency from furnishing a consumer report except for specified permissible purposes; the subscribers who received these reports did not have a permissible purpose to obtain them.
counts.conclusion: By and through the acts and practices described in Paragraph 16, ChoicePoint has violated Section 604(a) of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681b(a).

counts.title: Failure to Maintain Reasonable Procedures to Limit Furnishing of Consumer Reports (FCRA § 607(a))
counts.representation: ChoicePoint furnished consumer reports without maintaining reasonable procedures to limit furnishing to permissible purposes, without making reasonable efforts to verify the identity of prospective new users, without verifying the certified uses, and in circumstances where it had reasonable grounds to believe the reports would not be used for a permissible purpose.
counts.fact: Section 607(a) of the FCRA requires consumer reporting agencies to maintain reasonable procedures—including reasonable efforts to verify the identity and certified uses of each new prospective user—before furnishing consumer reports; Section 607(a) also prohibits furnishing reports when there are reasonable grounds to believe the report will not be used for a permissible purpose.
counts.conclusion: By and through the acts and practices described in Paragraphs 16, 19, and 21, ChoicePoint has violated Section 607(a) of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681e(a).

counts.title: Failure to Employ Reasonable Data Security Measures (FTC Act § 5(a))
counts.representation: ChoicePoint collected and sold personal consumer information without employing reasonable and appropriate security measures, including reasonable policies to verify or authenticate subscriber identities and qualifications, or to monitor or identify unauthorized subscriber activity.
counts.fact: ChoicePoint's failure to employ reasonable and appropriate security measures to protect consumers' personal information caused or was likely to cause substantial injury to consumers that was not offset by countervailing benefits and was not reasonably avoidable by consumers.
counts.conclusion: This practice was, and is, an unfair act or practice in or affecting commerce in violation of Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a).

counts.title: False or Misleading Privacy and Security Representations (FTC Act § 5(a))
counts.representation: Through its privacy principles disseminated on websites and in contracts, its ChoiceTrust website FCRA notices, and its FAQ letters to consumers, ChoicePoint represented that it had implemented reasonable and appropriate measures to maintain and protect the confidentiality and security of consumers' personal information, including a rigorous credentialing process for subscribers and procedures to monitor subscriber use of public record information.
counts.fact: In truth and in fact, ChoicePoint had not implemented reasonable and appropriate measures to maintain and protect the confidentiality and security of consumers' personal information, had not maintained a rigorous credentialing process to prevent persons without a lawful purpose from obtaining access to consumers' personal information, and had not implemented procedures to monitor subscribers' use of its public record information to ensure appropriate use.
counts.conclusion: Therefore, the representations set forth in Paragraphs 27 through 29 were, and are, false or misleading in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and constitute deceptive acts or practices in or affecting commerce.

provisions.title: Biennial Assessment Requirements
provisions.summary: Defendant must obtain biennial assessments from a qualified, independent third-party professional covering specified reporting periods, with each assessment setting forth safeguards, explaining their appropriateness, and certifying the effectiveness of the security program.

requirements.description: Defendant shall obtain assessments and reports from a qualified, objective, independent third-party professional using generally accepted procedures and standards, covering specified reporting periods including August 16, 2008 to August 15, 2010; August 16, 2010 to February 3, 2011; every two years from February 4, 2011 to February 3, 2025; and February 4, 2025 to February 15, 2026

requirements.description: Each Assessment shall be prepared and completed within sixty (60) days after the end of the reporting period by a person qualified as a CISSP, CISA, holding GIAC certification from the SANS Institute, or a similarly qualified person or organization approved by the Associate Director for Enforcement, Bureau of Consumer Protection, FTC

requirements.description: Within fifteen (15) days after each Assessment is prepared and completed, Defendant shall notify the Commission that the Assessment has been prepared and completed and provide: (1) name, address, phone number, and credentials of the third-party professional; (2) an overview of the administrative, technical, and physical safeguards evaluated; and (3) proof of certification from the third-party professional as required under Paragraph I.D of this Second Supplemental Order

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Second Supplemental Order.

requirements.description: This Court shall retain jurisdiction of this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Second Supplemental Order

provisions.title: Costs and Attorney's Fees
provisions.summary: Each party shall bear its own costs and attorney's fees incurred in connection with this action.

requirements.description: Each party shall bear its own costs and attorney's fees incurred in connection with this action

provisions.title: Notice of Entry of Supplemental Order
provisions.summary: Entry of this Second Supplemental Order in the court docket constitutes notice to Defendant of its terms and conditions, and Defendant waives all rights to contest proper service in any future proceeding.

requirements.description: Entry in the docket of this Second Supplemental Order by the Clerk of Court shall constitute notice to Defendant of the terms and conditions of this Second Supplemental Order, and Defendant waives all rights to contest in any future proceeding whether Defendant was properly served with this Second Supplemental Order

duration.termination_text: Every two years from February 4, 2011 to February 3, 2025; and February 4, 2025 to February 15, 2026. Provided however, that the Commission, at its sole discretion, may require Defendant to obtain up to two additional Assessments covering the two two-year periods following the final Assessment Period ending February 15, 2026, if the FTC provides the Defendant with written notice between February 15, 2024 and August 15, 2025, stating that the first such additional Assessment will be required, and/or written notice, between February 15, 2026 and August 15, 2027 that the second additional Assessment will be required.
